{{other uses|Halo Effect (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | name = The Halo Effect
...and the Eight Other Business Delusions that Deceive Managers | image = The-halo-effect-by-phil-rosenzweig.jpg | caption = Hardcover edition | author = Phil Rosenzweig | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Management]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = The Free Press | pub_date = {{start date|2007|2|6}} | english_pub_date = | media_type = [[Hardcover]] | pages = 232 | isbn = 978-0-7432-9125-5 | dewey = 658 22 | congress = HD30.19 .R67 2007 | oclc = 70265638 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Halo Effect''''' is a book by business academic Phil Rosenzweig that criticizes [[pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] tendencies in the explanation of business performance. The book was published by Free Press on February 6, 2007. As well as many business magazines and newspapers, the text targets specific books (those that offer secrets of guaranteed business success) and academic research published by [[business schools]]. It outlines nine "delusions": mistakes of reasoning that undermine these recipes for business success. In light of these mistakes, Rosenzweig argues, much of business writing is what [[Richard Feynman]] called "[[cargo cult science]]", having the superficial trappings of [[science]] but operating at the level of [[narrative|story-telling]]. The book also considers some more scientific business research, whose conclusions are more rigorous but do not promise a simple recipe for success. The subtitle of the 2007 US edition is "and the Eight Other Business Delusions that Deceive Managers" while that of the 2008 UK edition is "How Managers Let Themselves Be Deceived". The book was named "Business Book of the Year" 2007 at the [[Frankfurt Book Fair]].{{cite news|title=Business Books: Titles that got attention in 2007 | work=Reuters|date=December 6, 2007|author=Lisa Von Ahn |publisher=Thomas Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/mediaNews/idUSN0539788520071206|accessdate=2009-07-02}} It has been described as part of a trend for books that encourage [[evidence-based practice]] in business research.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/articles/2009/04/12/luck_inc/|title=Luck, Inc.: The 7 secrets of really, really lucky companies|last=Bennett|first=Drake |date=April 12, 2009 |work=The Boston Globe|accessdate=2009-07-02}} ==Background== The author told reporters the book had been written over the course of 25 years of experience in business consultancy and academia. Rosenzweig earned his PhD at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], before serving on the faculty at [[Harvard Business School]] and later at the [[International Institute for Management Development]] in Switzerland. His corporate career included seven years at [[Hewlett-Packard]]. ==Synopsis== ===Targets=== The book is critical of a genre of business books including ''[[In Search of Excellence]]'', ''[[Good to Great]]'', ''What Really Works'' and ''[[Built to Last: Successful Habits of Visionary Companies|Built to Last]]''. It finds similar faults with a swathe of [[business journalism]]. ===Nine delusions=== # ''The Halo Effect'' of the book's title refers to the [[Halo effect|cognitive bias]] in which the perception of one quality is contaminated by a more readily available quality (for example good-looking people being rated as more intelligent).{{cite journal|last=Nisbett |first=Richard E.|author2=Timothy D. Wilson |year=1977|title=The halo effect: Evidence for unconscious alteration of judgments|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|publisher=American Psychological Association|volume=35|issue=4|pages=250–256|issn=1939-1315|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.35.4.250 |url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/92158/1/TheHaloEffect.pdf}} In the context of business, observers think they are making judgements of a company's customer-focus, quality of leadership or other virtues, but their judgement is contaminated by indicators of company performance such as [[share price]] or [[Profit (accounting)|profitability]]. [[Correlations]] of, for example, customer-focus with business success then become meaningless, because success was the basis for the measure of customer focus. # ''The Delusion of Correlation and Causality:'' mistakenly thinking that [[correlation is not causation|correlation is causation]]. # ''The Delusion of Single Explanations:'' arguments that factor X improves performance by 40% and factor Y improves by another 40%, so both at once will result in an 80% improvement. The fallacy is that X and Y might be very strongly correlated. E.g. X might improve performance by causing Y. # ''The Delusion of Connecting the Winning Dots:'' looking only at successful companies and finding their common features, without comparing them against unsuccessful companies. # ''The Delusion of Rigorous Research:'' Some authors boast of the amount of data that they have collected, as though that in itself made the conclusions of the research valid. # ''The Delusion of Lasting Success:'' the "secrets of success" books imply that lasting success is achievable, if only managers will follow their recommended approach. Rosenzweig argues that truly lasting success (outperforming the market for more than a generation) never happens in business. # ''The Delusion of Absolute Performance:'' market performance is down to what competitors do as well as what the company itself does. A company can do everything right and yet still fall behind. # ''The Delusion of the Wrong End of the Stick:'' getting cause the wrong way round. E.g. successful companies have a Corporate Social Responsibility policy. Should we infer that CSR contributes to success, or that profitable companies have money to spend on CSR? # ''The Delusion of Organisational Physics:'' the idea that business performance is non-chaotically determined by discoverable factors, so that there are rules for success out there if only we can find them. ==Reception== Favourable reviews of the book included ''[[Forbes]]'',{{cite web|work=Forbes.com |title=Debunking Some Hot Business Books |date=June 3, 2007 |url= https://www.forbes.com/2007/03/06/ibm-cisco-starbucks-ent-manage-cx_kw_0306whartonhalo.html |accessdate=2009-07-02}} ''[[The Independent]]'',{{cite news|work=The Independent |first=Mike|last=Foster |date=March 9, 2008 |title=City Eye: From heroes to zeros – the cult of personality will punish chief executives|publisher=Independent News and Media|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/comment/city-eye-from-heroes-to-zeros-ndash-the-cult-of-personality-will-punish-chief-executives-793298.html?r=RSS |accessdate=2009-07-02}} and the ''[[Financial Times]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.johnkay.com/2007/05/08/leaders-should-say-goodbye-to-their-haloes|title=Leaders should say goodbye to their haloes |last=Kay|first=John|date=May 8, 2007|work=Financial Times|accessdate=2009-07-02}} ''Financial Times'' columnist Stefan Stern wrote that Rosenzweig "deserves acclaim for this brave, provocative piece of work"{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d86ee492-9ace-11db-bbd2-0000779e2340.html?nclick_check=1|title=Superstar yarns that dazzle and delude|last=Stern|first=Stefan|date=January 3, 2007|work=The Financial Times|accessdate=2009-07-02}} and included ''The Halo Effect'' in his top business books of the year.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/7b3921e6-a13c-11dc-9f34-0000779fd2ac.html|title=The best books of 2007|last=Gurria-Quintana|first=Angel |date=December 7, 2007|work=Financial Times|accessdate=2009-07-02}} ''The Halo Effect'' topped a Forbes.com list of "Five Must-Read Books For The Chastened CEO In 2009," which described it as a "delightful critique, which systematically destroys the entire management jujitsu oeuvre".{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/01/06/ceo-books-2009-leadership-ceo-cx_ds_0106books.html|title=Five Must-Read Books For The Chastened CEO In 2009|last=Shaywitz|first=David A.|date=June 1, 2009|work=Forbes.com|accessdate=2009-07-02}} The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' recommended the book for its "trenchant view of business and business advice".{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119845663787447953?mod=todays_us_nonsub_marketplace|title=Some Holiday Books About Inspiration And Delusion at Work |last=Hymowitz|first=Carol|date=December 24, 2007|work=Wall Street Journal|publisher=Dow Jones & Company|accessdate=2009-07-02}} ''[[USA Today]]'''s reviewer wrote, "That a management book can be at once scientific and a palatable read is a credit to Rosenzweig's writing style and clear thinking."{{cite news| work=USA Today| title=Level-headed book exposes some wrong business thinking |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/books/reviews/2007-02-19-halo-effect-usat_x.htm |accessdate=2009-06-02 |first=Michelle |last=Archer |date=February 19, 2007}} A favorable review in ''[[The Guardian]]'' called it a "feisty and entertaining new book".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/mar/18/theobserver.observerbusiness14|title=The snares and delusions of pseudoscience|last=Caulkin|first=Simon|date=March 18, 2007 |work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News & Media|accessdate=2009-07-02}} Columnist [[Simon Hoggart]] also mentioned it as a "refreshing corrective" to human gullibility.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/mar/17/politicalcolumnists.politics|title=English joy and French sang-froid|last=Hoggart|first=Simon|date=March 17, 2007|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News & Media|accessdate=2009-07-02}} A 2008 paper in the ''Journal of Corporate Accounting & Finance'' complains that the corporate world is infected with "best practicism"; the illusion that industry leadership can be made inevitable by following a simple formula. It cites ''The Halo Effect'' as an "outstanding" book.{{cite journal|journal=Journal of Corporate Accounting & Finance |year=2008 |publisher= Wiley Periodicals |title=The Myth of best practices |first=Anand |last=Sanwal|volume=19 |issue=5 |pages=51–60 |doi=10.1002/jcaf.20417 }} ''[[Newsweek]]'' said the book "employs an empirical rigor often lacking in business journalism" but complains that Rosenzweig "has little to offer" to replace the books he critiques.{{cite news|last=Sparks|first=John|title=Quick Read|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2007/03/18/quick-read.html|accessdate=10 January 2011|newspaper=Newsweek|date=March 19, 2007}} ==See also== {{portal|Business}} *[[Blindspots analysis]] *''[[Fooled by Randomness]]'' by Nicolas Nassim Taleb * ''[[Good to Great]]'' * ''[[In Search of Excellence]]'' ==Further reading== * {{cite journal|title=The halo effect, and other managerial delusions|date=February 2007 |first= Phil |last=Rosenzweig |publisher=McKinsey & Company |url=http://www.mckinseyquarterly.com/The_halo_effect_and_other_managerial_delusions_1928 |accessdate=2009-07-03|journal=McKinsey Quarterly}} * {{cite news|work=Marketing Week|title=Business success stories are masterpieces of fiction.|date=March 8, 2007|last=Mitchell |first=Alan |publisher=Centaur Publishing}} * {{cite web|work=Business Intelligence Network Newsletter |publisher=Powell Media |first=Steve |last=Miller|date=July 31, 2007 | title=Interview with Phil Rosenzweig, Author of The Halo Effect | url=http://www.b-eye-network.com/view/5649 |accessdate=2009-07-02 }} * {{cite journal|title=Misunderstanding the nature of company performance: the halo effect and other business delusions |year=2007 |first= Phil |last=Rosenzweig|journal=California Management Review |volume=49 | issue=4 |pages=6–20 |issn=0008-1256 |publisher=Emerald Group Publishing |doi=10.2307/41166403}} * {{cite news|work=Business Report |location=South Africa |url=http://www.busrep.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4066243 |accessdate=2009-07-02 |first=Vuyo|last=Jack |date=October 7, 2007 |title=Discovering the delusions of the business world}} {{Dead [[File:Víctor Pey 04-09-2015 cropped.jpg|thumb|Pey in 2015]] '''Víctor Pey Casado''' (31 August 1915 – 5 October 2018) was a Spanish-born Chilean engineer, professor, and businessman.
He was born in [[Madrid]], the son of writer and priest [[Segismundo Pey Ordeix]], and Manuela Casado, from Valladolid.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Galvez |first1=Julio |title=Winnipeg: Testimonios de un exilio |date=2014 |publisher=Renacimiento |isbn=978-84-16246-00-7 |page=288}}</ref> At the age of two, he moved with his family to [[Barcelona]]. During the [[Spanish Civil War]], he fought on the Republican side and was a member to the [[Durruti Column]]. He formed part of the Spanish government in exile as a technical advisor to the War Industries Commission of Catalonia. after being captured in France. He crossed the Pyrenees into France on 25 January 1939 and was captured and sent to a prison camp at [[Perpignan]].<ref name="cumple">{{cite news |last1=Ekaiser |first1=Ernesto |title=Víctor cumple 100 años |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2015/08/30/opinion/1440952135_849222.html |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=[[El Pais]] |date=29 August 2015}}</ref> In September 1939, [[Pablo Neruda]] arranged that Pey and his family board the [[SS Winnipeg]] for Chile.<ref name="mostrador">{{cite news |title=Adiós a un histórico en un día emblemático: a los 103 años fallece Víctor Pey, dueño de El Clarín |url=http://www.elmostrador.cl/noticias/pais/2018/10/05/adios-a-un-historico-a-los-103-anos-fallece-victor-pey-dueno-de-el-clarin/ |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=El Mostrador |date=5 October 2018}}</ref>
After arriving in [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]], he found work as a surveyor, together with the engineer José Saitúa, who was in charge of the construction of an aqueduct between Laguna Negra and Santiago.<ref>Galvez 2014, p. 307</ref> Pey became a naturalized Chilean citizen and worked with his brother Raúl in an engineering company. Pey met [[Salvador Allende]] during a party hosted by [[Aníbal Jara]], editor of La Hora newspaper. When Allende became President in 1970, Pey became an advisor to the [[Popular Unity (Chile)|Popular Unity]] government and was one of his closest associates.<ref name="desconcierto">{{cite news |title=Murió Víctor Pey a los 103 años: El adiós a un sobreviviente de la guerra civil española, fundador del Clarín y colaborador de Salvador Allende |url=http://www.eldesconcierto.cl/2018/10/05/murio-victor-pey-a-los-103-anos-el-adios-a-un-sobreviviente-de-la-guerra-civil-espanola-fundador-del-clarin-y-colaborador-de-salvador-allende/ |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=El Desconcierto |date=5 October 2018}}</ref> He purchased the newspaper [[Clarín (Chilean newspaper)|El Clarín]] during Allende's presidency, which became the largest newspaper in Chile.<ref>{{cite news |title=Muere en Chile a los 103 años Víctor Pey, refugiado español amigo de Allende |url=https://www.eldiario.es/politica/Muere-Chile-Victor-Pey-Allende_0_822067788.html |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=[[El Diario (Spain)|El Diario]] |date=6 October 2018}}</ref> After the [[Pinochet dictatorship]] was imposed in 1973, El Clarín was shut down. Pey was persecuted by the military junta and went into exile, not returning until the 1990s.<ref name="mostrador"/>
In 1997, Pey initiated a lawsuit against the Chilean government in the World Bank Tribunal for the expropriation of his newspaper. Successive Chilean administrations held the position of not paying Pey. After a 19-year legal battle, the case was dismissed without Pey receiving any damages.<ref name="mostrador"/>
Pey identified as an agnostic.<ref name="cumple"/> He was named honorary rector of the [[University of Chile]] in 2015, coinciding with his centenary. He died of natural causes on 5 October 2018, aged 103.<ref name="desconcierto"/>
